content: Apparently, after it removes my sent messages from the system's "Sent" folder, the system has been saving all of my sent messages to the ”Archives Folder” in (the name of my account) (on the Thunderbird hardware) in “Yearly archived folders”, because , I have been using the “Archive Messages” option under “Copies and Folders” option under (the name of my account) to “Keep message archives” in the ”Archives Folder” in (the name of my account)(on the Thunderbird hardware) with the “Archive options” button set to store the messages in “Yearly archived folders”. I am planning to have the system start saving these sent messages in Local Folders on my local computer to avoid filling up my space on the Thundebird hardware.
creator: nkennington@juno.com

content: The simple way is to right-click on the menu bar at top of message list pane and tick 'junk status.' That adds a column in the pane that lets you easily select junk and non-junk. Be sure to periodically do this for the good and the bad, so Thunderbird learns. If you only specify what is not junk, thunderbird never learns well.
creator: davidsk

content: One possibility is to go to settings>composition and UNtick the option to save drafts. OR, under accountsettings, copies&folders, set draft folder to local drive.
creator: davidsk

content:
My understanding is that recent versions of thunderbird do not store allmail folder on local drive and Google manages it. However, on your question, a simple approach about using the other drive would be to move the full account over to the external drive. To do that: - exit thunderbird - in windows file explorer, locate the account at c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles\<profilename>\imapmail\imap.gmail.com (assuming account is imap and gmail) and copy to the other drive. - start thunderbird - highlight account, rightclick and select 'settings' - select 'server settings' - click the browse button and locate/select the folder you placed on external drive - test account to be sure all is working normally. - exit thunderbird - in windows file explorer, you may now delete the folder at imapmail\account name

Tip: If you don't use the Allmail account, you can just highlight account, select 'subscribe' and unsubscribe from the folder. Also check under 'synchronization&storage 'advanced' tab to ensure you do not have the folder selected for offline use.
creator: davidsk

That works on K-9 Mail on my Android phone, but not on my Win 11 desktop Thunderbird. It just doesn't see any email using port 995; have to switch back to Port 110 and enable STARTTLS manually. Since it works on my phone, I'm sure that NS is configured to allow its use. Not really a problem, I hope. Just wondering why I can't get Port 995 to work!

content:
You didn't list everything. The incoming server name varies, but a common one is mobile.charter.net a common SMTP server is either mobile.charter.net or smtp.charter.net . Authentication for both is probably SSL/TLS

Try those and let us know. You could also contact the email provider (spectrum) and ask for specific email settings to confirm what I posted. Let us know of any errors.
creator: davidsk

content:
Assuming you want to use the old profile, and not the current profile, do this: - make the old profile available, such as on a USB stick. create the copy when Thunderbird is NOT running - on the university server, select tools>import>import from another installation and then select the desired profile within the ...appdata\thunderbird\profiles folder

OR..

with thunderbird installed and not running on university computer copy the ...appdata\thunderbird folder to the same location on university computer then start thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

Does problem go away?

content:
Depending on your email provider, the server may delete messages in the Trash folder after a certain time. With IMAP Thunderbird can only see what exists on the server. Check with your email provider.

Having said that, it sounds like a silly idea to me to use Trash as an archive folder. Thunderbird does have a built-in archiving feature. https://support.mozilla.org/kb/archived-messages

Wrt the lost messages, I'd backup stuff I don't want to lose. You could easily restore messages from a backup, assuming you did take the effort creating one in the first place.
creator: christ1

content:
christ1 said
Depending on your email provider, the server may delete messages in the Trash folder after a certain time.

I checked with my host and they do not delete IMAP email files (trash or otherwise). It's a mystery.

It's hard to know which messages will be needed 6 months or 2 years from now, but using the "Archive" feature is a good idea. Thanks.
